headline.main: From Beijing, the Memorable and the Not-So Memorable

docs.snippet: It is any outsider’s guess what happens next in China after a successful Olympics. We, like the Chinese proletariat, will have to wait, hope and see.
docs.lead_paragraph: It is any outsider's guess what happens next in China after a successful Olympics. Will there be increased political freedom after China opened its doors to the sports world? Or will there be renewed central authority, with 51 Chinese gold medals and zero major protests as proof that the great, paternalistic state knows exactly what it is doing?

docs.abstract: Correction of Aug 25 article reflecting on competition and spectacle of Beijing Olympics, regarding person referenced
docs.snippet: An article on Monday about the writer's impressions of the competition and spectacle of the Beijing Olympics misspelled, in some copies, the surname of a singer from Canada, which will be the host country of the 2010 Winter Games. She is Céline Dion
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the writer's impressions of the competition and spectacle of the Beijing Olympics misspelled, in some copies, the surname of a singer from Canada, which will be the host country of the 2010 Winter Games. She is Céline Dion, not Deon.

docs.abstract: Star athletes who competed in Olympic Games in Beijing are making their bids to cash in on China's boom in sports marketing and sponsorship deals; business has grown into $15-billion-a-year industry, up from about $1 billion in 1994; athletes who are cashing in on endorsements in China include basketball players Dwyane Wade and Kobe Bryant and tennis stars Serena and Venus Williams; photos (L)

headline.main: China's Promise Excites the Sports Stars

docs.snippet: At times during the Olympics, athletes like Dwyane Wade and Serena Williams seemed to be working as hard off the court as on they were on the court.      Mr. Wade, a star player for the Miami Heat, and Ms. Williams, the tennis sensation, courted the
docs.lead_paragraph: At times during the Olympics, athletes like Dwyane Wade and Serena Williams seemed to be working as hard off the court as on they were on the court. Mr. Wade, a star player for the Miami Heat, and Ms. Williams, the tennis sensation, courted the Chinese media, chatted online with Chinese sports fans, and strategized with their agents about how to tap into the rising Chinese market.

docs.abstract: Nana Shi, who lives in Beijing, first discovered fortune cookies on trip to America; she sells them through her company Beijing Fortune Cookies; photos (M)

headline.main: First, Crack Them Open (Like Americans Do!)

docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.snippet: Although most Americans think of fortune cookies as Chinese, they are all but unknown in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: THE instructions on the red wrapper are very explicit: (1) Open the packaging. (2) Use both hands to break open the fortune cookie. (3) Retrieve and read the fortune. (4) Eat the cookie. In China, such details are necessary, it seems.

docs.abstract: Chinese government is taking steps to shore up reputation of men's soccer team; although soccer is China's most popular sport, fans are continuously frustrated by dismal performance of men's team, most recently during Beijing Games; news organizations that have joined in mockery of team are ordered to stop; photo (M)

headline.main: China Defends Its Reviled Soccer Team

docs.snippet: BEIJING -- The Olympic Games have shown that sports and national pride are still tightly intertwined, and perhaps nowhere more so than in the minds of Chinese leaders.     The evidence is indisputable: the more than $40 billion spent on the Games, th

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG; Huang Yuanxi contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- The Olympic Games have shown that sports and national pride are still tightly intertwined, and perhaps nowhere more so than in the minds of Chinese leaders. The evidence is indisputable: the more than $40 billion spent on the Games, the record haul of 51 gold medals by Chinese athletes, the invitations to 80 world leaders to attend the opening ceremony.

docs.abstract: Fencer Andrea de Mello heads to Beijing, China, as member of United States wheelchair fencing team; photo (M)

headline.main: Pushing the Limit, a Fencer Is Heading to the Paralympics, in a Wheelchair

docs.snippet: Andrea de Mello, who has been training for the past 23 years to regain some of the athletic ability she lost to a stroke as an adolescent, is headed to Beijing.
docs.lead_paragraph: First, she had to conquer the lampposts. Before Andrea de Mello ran 20 marathons, and before she fenced for Brazil at the Paralympic Games in Atlanta; Sydney, Australia; and Athens, she stood at a lamppost next to Central Park and wondered whether she could walk to the next one.

headline.main: ‘Art and China’s Revolution’ at Asia Society

docs.snippet: The Asia Society offers a modest but explosive kernel of a show on the history of culture and politics in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Asia Society offers a modest but explosive kernel of a show on the history of culture and politics in China.

headline.main: International Envoys Discuss North Korea Nuclear Complex

docs.snippet: International envoys from four nations started meetings in Beijing on Friday, seeking clarification on whether North Korea has begun reassembling its main nuclear complex.

byline.original: By CHOE SANG-HUN and GRAHAM BOWLEY; Choe Sang-hun reported from Seoul, South Korea, and Graham Bowley from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea -- International envoys from four nations started meetings in Beijing on Friday, seeking clarification on whether North Korea has begun reassembling its main nuclear complex, its only known source of bomb-making plutonium. The United States' top nuclear envoy, Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill said late Friday night after meetings in Beijing that the United States was willing to sit down again with representatives from the five other countries involved in the disarmament talks, according to the Associated Press.

docs.abstract: Barbara Buchan wins gold medal and sets world record at Beijing Paralympic Games in 3,000-meter cycling pursuit; and wins gold medal; had to overcome physical and cognitive problems suffered in near-fatal bicycle crash 26 years ago to win; photos (M)

headline.main: From Death's Door To Medal Stand

docs.snippet: Customers at the Bend, Ore., Home Depot can get impatient when the middle-aged woman in gardening cannot quite process a simple question -- ''Where are the light bulbs?'' -- and asks them to write the words on the pad she carries. But sometimes that
docs.lead_paragraph: Customers at the Bend, Ore., Home Depot can get impatient when the middle-aged woman in gardening cannot quite process a simple question -- ''Where are the light bulbs?'' -- and asks them to write the words on the pad she carries. But sometimes that is what it takes before she can answer, ''Oh, Aisle 4.'' Twenty-six years after a near-fatal bicycle accident left her comatose for two months and with permanent brain injuries, the saleswoman, Barbara Buchan, performs many actions more slowly than others. But on Wednesday in Beijing, she did one thing in world-record time.

docs.abstract: Eleven people who came to Beijing to demonstrate outside main Olympic stadium against property losses in city of Liuzhou are surrounded by police officers from their hometown; government requires citizens to register to protest and has yet to grant any permits to people to hold lawful protests in three parks in Beijing designated for purpose; photo (M)

headline.main: Would-Be Protesters Find the Olympics Failed to Expand Free Speech in Beijing

docs.snippet: People who were kept from protesting are skeptical that there has been any real increase in freedom of speech, despite the hopes of the International Olympic Committee.
docs.lead_paragraph: Eleven people came here to the capital on Monday, bent on protesting property losses. They were experienced, having been to Beijing before to petition the central government. They were familiar, all coming from the same town and having been locked up in the same jails. They were crafty, flying up on two planes from a third city, rather than taking the train from their own, and lying low for two days before trying anything. But they never had a chance.
